												I constantly find myself torn by games like Gemini Rue; on the one hand, they exude aesthetic and narrative charm, with lovingly crafted characters, worlds, and stories, which are always the main reason I and many others are drawn to them, but on the other hand they are almost always a desperately frustrating gaming experience, bogged down by puzzles that are long, disjointed, and (in many cases) narratively inappropriate.The latter issue is what bugs me the most, and what makes playing these games so frustrating. For example, there is one particular puzzle where you need to call a guy using your communicator and try to get some information out of him. If you don’t choose the specifically correct dialogue options when speaking to him, he hangs up. This is quite believable and is probably what an actual human would do. Of course, this game being what it is, you can just call him again and again and again and try a different set of dialogue options each time, and every single time he responds as though you’re speaking to him for the first time. It doesn’t matter how many times you call him – even on the fifth call, he responds as though you’ve not just spoke to him four times previously using ever so slightly different variations on your script. If this were an actual person speaking to another human being, calling the person again and trying the same script with tiny variations would get you laughed at and hung up on immediately.The above kind of puzzle is narratively inappropriate because it is just not how a human being would behave at all. The playing experience stops being a nicely flowing story of which you, the gamer, are an integral part, and becomes an arbitrary clicking exercise, jarring you out of the narrative. The above puzzle is also guilty of another puzzle design sin: it seems to exist solely to pad out the game. It isn’t hard, don’t require much thought, and just involves trying different combinations over and over again, wasting a lot of time in the process. I wish I could say this was the only example of this, but it sadly isn’t.Many of the puzzles in Gemini Rue aren’t game ruining, and they aren’t completely nonsensical (unlike other infamous examples from this genre: the rubber ducky puzzle in The Longest Journey, anyone?) but they are generally quite wonky and boring. At one point you have to find a Carbon Ray Stabilizer to fix your lockpicks (why a Carbon Ray Stabilizer, I have no idea). Rather than buying it from a vendor or asking someone where to find one, you have to search around an abandoned building with some crates hidden towards the back. It’s not even easy to get to the crates – you have to get someone to help you. You have to see the crates when exploring, think “hang on, they must be really important” not “they’re just some old crates at the back of an abandoned room” and then go out of your way to work out how to get to them. Lo and behold, there’s one in the crates. Why is it there? I have no idea. I was just aimlessly exploring because I had no idea what to do next and just so happened to stumble on the solution. That’s not a satisfying solution to the problem, and it makes absolutely no narrative sense. The strange thing is that I often feel like I’m crazy for feeling this way; support for old-school point and click games seems overwhelming, and any critical opinions seem to be drowned in a sea of nostalgic rage. I seriously want to love games like this, I really do, but their puzzles make them a gargantuanly frustrating experience. If you’re willing to have a walkthrough in one hand at all times and you’re willing to suspend your disbelief through some poorly designed puzzles, then I would probably recommend this. Unfortunately, I felt frustrated more than I felt enjoyment, which is not something I want to experience in a game.

												About an hour into the game, Gemini Rue makes a massive misstep in the fusion of game mechanics and narrative which wrenched me out of this initially immersive little world. I do admire the creators for introducing gun fights into a point and click adventure. Gun fights where you can actually lose your life, and for a moment they introduced some tangible excitement and danger into the story. The game drills into you the idea of conserving your ammo, putting yourself at risk in order to get a more accurate, deadlier shot and therefore save a few bullets. And then it happens. You're in a corridor, you have 8 bullets, with enemies on your tail. Your character gets behind cover and a shootout ensues. An enemy is leaning out and firing wildly, but you're patient, calculating the timing of your enemy's shots. When you spot a window you lean out, and you focus your attention on just this one shot, not a bullet to waste. Of course you're exposed as you do this; it's a risky action. But you can't fire with wild abandon like them. You have to save ammo.Your pursuer leans out. Bang. A bullet in his head. It feels good, you've bought yourself some time. You and your partner run down to the end of the corridor to make your escape. And then you - YOU - your virtual persona. The character you have been inhabiting, controlling and roleplaying for the last hour forcibly stops at the foot of those stairs which lead to safety. He turns back towards the corridor. The computer has taken control of you. The story kicks in.Your avatar: "I've got to hold them off!"bangbangbangbangbangbangbangExactly 7 shots. You counted them. Every last bullet, fired pointlessly into the ether by the computer. Your character then turns up the stairs and thus begins a dumb timed puzzle where you have to break down a door before a bad guy bursts in and shoots your stupid, defenseless, magazine-emptying idiot of an avatar. If only you could have just kept running up those stairs and saved those bullets for when the bad guys followed you up there. I died a few times and had to replay this scene. Each time I performed a bit differently during that first shootout (where I had control) and I used up a different amount of bullets.The real kick in the balls here is that the game programmatically counts how many bullets you used up, and then once the computer takes over control it fires the exact amount of rounds that you had remaining. They actually did that. They coded that. This is something worse than terrible game design. It actually feels like being trolled by the developers.

 Gemini Rue First impressions: A game where you become a "Blade Runner"-style cop in a "Blade Runner"-style world. Seems uninteresting? At first it's boring. I admit it. But then, as soon the game's cryptic nature slowly unveils: a symphony is played. The plot is the real thing here, for IT IS THE GAME. Everything lean on it. This detective story is not an ordinary one, it's more a tale than a noire. There will be a plot twist, but it's a twist that is not trivial at all. It is a fight between light and dark, good versus bad in a corrupt and decayed galaxy (cyberpunk-theme). Cons are the puzzles, they are too easy and gunfights are a little clanky, nevertheless these are just two little faults on an overall masterpiece.Let's get down to brass tacks:Genre: point-and-click/sci-fi/cyberpunk adventure/noireAI: irrelevant.Difficulty: easy (there are no real challenges, it's more a tale than an actual game).Plot: great plot. Playing this game is like reading a solid sci-fi book. Atmosphere: dark and decayed. This game is great mainly because it uses "ancient" graphics ('90s) through which is difficult to convey emotions. The dev team achieved this and for this they have to be commended. GREAT JOB!Graphics: voluntarily outdated. It's more a game with substance than appearance. It has a lot to talk about so graphics is not a core value.Audio: voluntarily old. This serves just as the "thing" that glue-up together atmosphere, plot and ultimately fun: without voices and/or sounds the game would be boring in my opinion.  FUN FACTOR: investigating an ever-raining-mining planet under the guise of a cop while at the same time another person tries to survive within a space station. Well, it is adventurous is it not? Thus we can say it is...FUN! Conclusion: a game that focuses on both atmosphere and plot. "Substance is what it counts" it seems to say. Are you interested in exploring a dark city and try to beat the odds? Did you like Ridley Scott's Blade Runner? If yes then: get it!Thanks for reading.

Outstanding adventure game.I didn't realise that classic adventure games could be so immersive! I enjoyed latest Telltale work, but I would hardly place them in adventure genre. Gemini Rue on the other hand is a real classic point-and-click adventure game, though you could say that the biggest flaws and offenders of the genre were left out. You won't find any illogical obstacles and puzzles, pixel hunting or absurd item combining. What you get is a great sci-fi noiresque story, where you are a detective looking for his lost brother on some god-forgotten planet. Later the game opens up and lets you switch between the two main characters, the detective and the missing brother. It really does feel like you're detective, getting dirty and doing the groundwork: asking around, getting true identity of people, searching information about them in database. Top this with action sequences where you can cover and shoot at your enemies and you really get an exceptional adventure game. Voice acting and writing is astounding and the story itself is intriguing and suprising. All of that in a indie game made by the handful of people! I did enjoy the visual style of the game and I think it befits the game, but I guess some people could argue that the resolution is too low. Overall, superb game, highly recommended. A great reminder that the adventure games are a great way to tell a story and don't have to be obscure and plagued with bizzare puzzles.

												I think this is one of the greatest science fiction point-and-click adventure games you could find on steam. It's got old school pixel graphics and just great voice acting all-around. The puzzle elements are also a lot of fun. The story behind Gemini Rue may seem derivative. It's set in a universe like the TV show Firefly and it's movie counterpart Serenity, it has the tone and feel of Blade Runner and has the plot of Total Recall. But it never made it bad. It's just taking the good stuff on what I like about science fiction.You play as Azriel Odin, an ex-assassin that is looking for his brother on the planet of Barrucus, which is part of a Gemini Star System, a system that won it's independence after a war and is now run by a crime syndicate known as the Boryokudun. The other character you will get to play is Delta-Six whom is a patient of a mysterious facility. This is all I can say about the story without going into spoilers.Throughout the game, you talk to characters, solve puzzles, do detective-like work to learn about things and occasionally go on shoot-outs. There's an interesting shooting mechanic in the game that you will learn how to use. All of the characters in Gemini Rue are well written and feel real. The philosophical themes of identity and memories are also explored in this game and is pretty much what the game wants to explore and talk about. There are a couple downsides of this game. Some of the puzzles are little too difficult and the fictional universe that is offered in Gemini Rue remains mostly unexplored with the exception of a single city on one planet and a facility somewhere else.But I recommend this game to Science fiction, cyberpunk and story adventure fans. It's definitely a must-buy!

												An engaging and immersive cyberpunk point n click adventure game with a great story and likeable characters. The story has interesting themes and is portrayed in an interesting fashion. The voice acting fit the characters well and they were all unique. I also liked how the music was very understated and complimented the scenes nicely. It was definitely satisfying to play through to the end and see how the story unfolded, leaving a very satisfying conclusion.The graphics are beautifully drawn and make the world feel immersive. Some backgrounds are only seen for a few seconds yet are still richly detailed and almost breathtaking to look at, so I commend the developer for that.The puzzles hit the right balance between challenging and logical, there weren't any weird and crazy parts of the game's internal logic. Some areas of the game can be a little tricky and annoying to figure out which part of the map to go to next as you backtrack through familiar areas a few times but nothing too egregious.There is combat through gunplay. Instead of just pressing the use button on gun and clicking on an enemy in a traditional point n click style, there is combat where the player takes cover, aims, and has to time their shots in the minigame. While it isn't very complex, it breaks up the puzzles and provide an interesting way of doing action in a style of game like this. I noticed a couple of glitches such as when a sprite in the background would be placed on the top layer in front of my character in the foreground, but this only happened twice.Definitely recommended for people who enjoy interesting sci-fi cyberpunk stories with good voice acting and story, especially considering that the majority was drawn, written and programmed by just one student, so props to him for making such an engaging and interesting game. Worth checking out, especially for the really neat easter eggs.

												Gemini Rue ReviewA Noir-sci-fi point and click adventure game, Gemini Rue is the project of sole developer Joshua Neunberger. headlining hand-drawn backgrounds spanning several planets and locations, and an expansive story, Gemini rue has won numerous awards for its story and style.The story drags you in right from the start, beginning with a man in a chamber (i won't say any more than that) and then immediately switching to someone waiting under a shelter in the rain. The atmosphere is thick, accentuated by the quiet Noir soundtrack and the ever-pouring rain. The puzzles are good, with the occasional frustrating pixel hunt. With two story threads, and the ability to switch between them, the game never really gets boring; if you get tired of one character, you can easily switch to the other. The game has voice acting, which is surprisingly good for an indie game. The dialogue is decent, and the pixel art suits the game. Once you have finished the around 6-7 hour story, you can enable developer commentary, which gives you an inside look at the development process as well as some funny bloopers. I played first on Windows, but i decided to try developer commentary on mac, and discovered how buggy it was. The cursor stuck to the edges of the screen, you had to option-click for right click, and you couldnt scroll your inventory. Now for the pros and cons list.pros:+Excellent atmosphere+great, engaging story+passable voice acting+decent artwork and style+good developer commentary+ambient noir soundtrack+different main characterscons:-slightly clunky interface-some puzzles are mindless pixel hunts-buggy on macfinal score:9.5/10

												Gemini Rue is like a 90s adventure game, for good and ill. For good because it stylistically fits right beside games like Rise of the Dragon, Dreamweb and Beneath a Steel Sky. In terms of mood there’s nothing wrong with it. The music, sound and visuals work together well. The problem lies with the dialog, which especially towards the end don’t deliver as strongly as it needed to. It’s so close, just another few editing passes might have done it. It doesn’t ruin it, it just stumbles across the finish line. I thought the conceit of the story was done ok. It’s not the best take on the concept, as I thought Dollhouse for example did it much better. But I thought it was alright for what it is.The game isn’t a must play. It's good, but not as brilliant as it could have been. But if you feel like playing something that's 90s style, this will deliver, pixel hunting and all.

Gemini Rue is excellent sci-fi, noir adventure game with some technical problems, but this must not stop you from enjoying it.The game takes place in 23rd century within “Gemini System”, a star system recently declared independence after 10 years of devastating war. After that crime sindycate named Boryokudan takes control much of the system. At the start of the game you take control of Azriel Odin, ex-assassin now turned to cop. He's searching information on planet Barracus about his missing brother Daniel. Through most of the game you will play with Azriel, but at some point you will take control of Daniel. I don't want to spoil the plot since this is the best thing in the game, but i'll say it includes conspiracy, memory wipe, superb twist, in other words – briliant story. Of course the good writing helps a lot. The ending is quite philosophical.Gameplay wise is pretty standard for the genre, with one exception. I'll talk about it later. You click on a hotspot and choose which part of the body (eye, hand, leg or mouth) or item will be used. After being stuck on 1 or 2 places i quickly realized that the leg icon is quite usefull for moving forward the story. Most of the adventure games i played don't have similar thing. Maybe the most important feature in adventure game are the puzzles. For me they were ideally tough, but veteran players probably will breeze through them. Maybe just 2 or 3 times i was stuck for a brief moment. Puzzels always have common sense and they are tight quite nice with plot. And because of this they are obvious, just listen the conversations. Puzzels include speaking with someone, start a machine, search for information in terminals and some have not the most elegant solutuons – shootng lock, breaking window and so on. The only thing missing is combining stuff in your inventory. Like i said the puzzels maybe easy for those who is looking for a mental challenge, so keep that in mind.The exception i meant was gunfights, Yes, it's a bit strange to have such a thing in adventure game, but they fit so well in the story and you won't mind them. They are total 5 or 6, so don't, it' not a side scroller shooter. The gunfights proceed like this: you stand behind cover, then you press A or D to show yourself from the left or right position of the cover and shoot. The enemy is doing the same thing. But you can one-hit kill the bad guys. There is a bar on upper left corner and by pressing a button you will concentrate and when it reaches the green zone it will guarantee headshot and quickly ending the shooting. And you can choose their the difficulty at any point. The game is autosaving before life-threatening situations.The graphics. Some parts are great, others – questionable. The game is a nod to old school adventure games and I like pixel art, space cutscene are good, character design and movement are good, but the backgrounds are bland. The levels are okay. You are on the rainy streets or inside a building. Just little more details in the environment won't hurt.The sound design is great. The voices for the main characters are great, but i can't say the same thing about some of the secondary. Most of the game doesn't have any music, but when it does, it's great. It's starts and stops abruptly and this is unfortunate.The biggest problems here comes from the technical side of things. The game runs at max resolution 1280x800 and it's locked at 40 frames per second. Sometimes Esc doesn't work. When this happen press Space bar and then Esc again. For me this is fixing the problem, i think. When you load save game half of the screen is black, until you move away from that scene, but this happen only 3 times through my whole playthrough.Gemini Rue is fantastic adventure. Right from the start the game intrigued me and i was glued to the screen, until i saw the end credits. It offers fantastic story, gritty sci-fi atmosphere, gunfights, light puzzels, but it suffers from some unfortunate technical problems. One more thing. Almost the whole game is made by a single person. This is quite impressive. I highly recommend it.

												A dystopian cyberpunk point-and-click indie game with atmospheric art direction and excellent sound design.Playing as a former assassin you're placed in the raining wet city of Pittsburg at night. The protagonist however is better suited to the voice, and is easily the best match.The game is quite short,  and can be completed in a sitting or two depending on how much time is spent on progressing through scenes. I completed it in Steam's Offline mode, so my actual play time isn't displayed publicly (note to devs: make it work for such singleplayer games).For those looking for a similar experience I'd highly recommended the Hideo Kojima classic Snatcher for the Sega CD. The voice acting, characters, dialog and humorous respite work together to make a very well-rounded and satisfying game.In short, I'd recommended Gemini Rue to those looking for a short, well-made and atmospheric cyberpunk-esque fix, and are open to the point-and-click style of gameplay.

												Ever wanted to go back to the mid-90's and play an adventure game?  Well- with this game, you're there!A sci-fi romp following a split story between a prisoner who lost his memory, and a detective- you point and click your way through this beast.Seemingly taking ideas from point'n'click adventures before it (Beneath a Steel Sky, Blade Runner, I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream), this one manages to meld the lot and create its own beast.Story is solid, with some twists in the tale, "trust noone".  Puzzles are plentiful, but sometimes a pain as items appear when a puzzle is solved on a completely different screen- or a dialogue box that you happened to have missed.  There are no "real" muliple endings, what you get is a linear story, but if you do something at the end you can get an extra line of dialogue.Graphics are very welcome.  Instead of looking "old", the lo-resolution pixel art gives the game character, screamingly familiar to a mid-90's adventure.  Effects, such as rain manage to give the world a sense of life, even though the setting is so dark.The zoomed in pictures in dialogue were OK at best.  Compared to the games smaller pixel art, it felt to me that these had far less character- most of the time not fitting to the ingame graphic and voice.  Without these, I felt the game would have created more of a link to the player with their character if it were just the pixel guys opening mouths and bobbing their heads.  I hope they include an option to turn off the dialogue graphics in their next game.Gameplay was mostly point and click, with a gun fight mini-game.  Point and click was standard,  right click and you can (eye), (hand), (foot) etc.  The game is fairly short at roughly 9 hours, and a few more if you want to find the achievements.There is a problem that you can't pull up your inventory to look at items (there is no inventory button).  In order to look at an item you need to right click on an ingame object, then right click on your item (makes little sense).Bugs:  There were some graphic bugs, but nothing game breaking.  I found that sometimes the right have of the screen was garbled after a load.  Also, if you have an instance of Chrome in the background, dialogues could not be shown / heard.  It was all skipped.  One screen also had a graphics "layering" problem, where the background was infront of the forground (groundfloor of the apt building).Overall;  Gemini Rue is a great point'n'click adventure that should've been released in the 90's... But it's out now!  There are a couple of bugs, but they don't break the game.  The amount of character and soul put into this project is worthy of a lookup, this is a game I'm proud to say I've completed.

												I wanted to like this game soo badly since I love all the Wadjet Eye games I've played so far - but I just couldn't bear to finish it. The user interface in this game is absolutely terrible and everything feels clunky/buggy. The story and graphics are great, but that's about it. There's no default actions for the most basic things such as having a left-click on a person start to talk or left-click on a door try to open it. You have to constantly right-click for everything which gets tedious. - Some of the hidden objects seem like they're two pixels in width so you can only find by mouse scanning versus being attentive to each scene- Puzzles are more difficult to solve due to user interface confusion. I aquired two objects, one which is needed to fix the other, and couldn't figure out how to use them on each other. Due to having to right-click an object to get that pop-up menu (also the only area to see your inventory), how do I combine two items that are both in my inventory?  Positive + A genuinely intriguing story in a futuristic noir setting; watching the mystery of Azriel Odin and Delta-Six unravel throughout the course of the 5 ½ hour campaign does not drag on in the slightest, with a satisfying conclusion to top it all off+ In the style of older point and click games (most notably Beneath a Steel Sky), Gemini Rue’s gameplay is a tried and tested formula that doesn’t fail to test the player at times with somewhat obscure puzzles, while still remaining fairly linear+ The game also manages to effectively capture the graphical style of said older games, with both pixelated environments and character models giving the game a distinctive look; the sound effects and music as well are very well-implemented+ The amateur voice acting that accompanies the story is surprisingly well-done--especially the main characters--making the games futuristic/noir setting all the more authentic. Negative - The few shooting sections, while a nice addition to the point and click gameplay, suffer from awkward controls and mechanics (luckily these sections are few and far between)- The amount of environments and backgrounds is scarce, leading to you treading familiar ground far too often; some more locations to explore wouldn’t go amiss. Verdict “Gemini Rue pays homage to point and click games from the past, while still managing to feel both old and new. With an unforgettable story and quirky puzzles, the few gameplay sections that may try to detract from the experience couldn’t manage to deter me from playing through this gem. I’d easily recommend this game to fans of old adventure games.” 8/10 TJBs

												Very nice game which is obviously trying very hard to draw parallels with both "Beneath a Steel Sky" and "Blade Runner". Storywise it's up there with the very best of sci-fi gaming, with plenty of mystery, intrigue and plot twists where you least expect them. It's very beautiful to look at, in a VGA sort of way....and the sound design is top notch too. I know some people didn't care for the voice acting but it seemed fine to me. Even if the "grizzled hardboiled" protagonist sounds like Harvey Fierstein imitating Marlon Brando :DUnfortunately the interface is needlessly cumbersome. Rather than, say, left-click to look and right-click to use like the aforementioned Sky which they so liberally borrow from, you have to right-click, choose which part of your body you want to use to interact with an item and then click on it. It gets even more complicated when you gain a sidekick and have to drag them around in the same way. If you come across a ladder, do you use your foot or your hand on it? Actually, either works, but why give us the choice? "Use" really should be context-appropriate nowadays as most of the choices the player is given are either stupid (You're not going to use your mouth on the ladder) or don't matter (hand or foot works)....Oh, points also deducted for introducing a needless real-time combat system. Adventure games don't need real-time combat. I thought we learned this with Harvester, Blade Runner, Maddog Williams....at least Full Throttle let you skip the arcade sections if you didn't want to do them....

												Gemini Rue is a mixed bag. Unfortunately, for me the good parts were outweighed by the game's many annoyances.On the positive side, Gemini Rue has pretty strong pixel art which holds up well in comparison to similar games from the Golden Age of adventure gaming. The palette choices work well in evoking a dystopian sci-fi atmosphere. The writing is pretty good too, with a couple of caveats--an overly predictable plot twist, and some eye-rolling philosophical monologue at the endgame. Voice acting is uneven, but serves its purpose. The music is quite good, but is sadly rather sparse.And now for a list of complaints:The artwork often obscures point-and-click hotspots. (It's not "hunt the pixel" bad, just needs some higher contrast and larger hotspots in a few places.)The option to skip some walking animations is taken away part-way through the game, and is never returned.There's no automation of obvious (and cumbersome) interactions. Card-access doorways, ladders, and elevators become annoying obstacles, with no gameplay benefit.A couple of puzzles are pretty bad. The "lights out" puzzle (which appears twice!) felt so out of place that it took me out of the game. Another puzzle left me with the impression that the player character is too stupid to figure out on his own how to plug in an extension cord.The control scheme for moving boxes is completely decoupled from the basic point-and-click mechanics. Why?Inventory management has a poor interface. If I want to read an inventory item, I have to first click an unrelated hotspot on the screen just to bring up the inventory.Most puzzle solutions are pleasingly rational, but we're not entirely free of the adventure game curse of "dream logic".There's a pretty good adventure game here, but it's sadly obscured by interface problems. If you are an adventure game fan who can look past some of these warts, you might be able to have a good time with Gemini Rue.

												It's a point-and-click adventure game of the older variety (puzzling puzzles and all), which, for some reason, puts some people off from the very outset. Assuming you're not from that group, however, you will find a game with a pretty unique and intriguing story, accompanied by a very fitting noir atmosphere (I hesitate to call it cyberpunk, though similar themes are employed) and well executed retro graphics. On the other hand, the story and the atmosphere are the good parts of the game.Why do I say that? Well, even when it works the controls, particularly those for shooting, are a bit of an annoyance. The game would've been better without those action sequences, but alas, they're there and can be endured. The main complaint, however, is that the game is rather buggy in game-breaking ways. There are workarounds, but it still makes it a bad product. For example, on Windows 7 x64, the first thing one has to do is to turn the Steam overlay off, or else any alt-tabbing or shift-tabbing means that all dialogue will be in fast-forward mode, making it impossible to follow the plot. Resonance, another game from the same developer, has the same issue, so at least I kind of knew about it.Next, after a restart my saves just disappeared. Turns out this can be fixed by moving them from \SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\Gemini Rue\reslists\Savesto \SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\Gemini Rue\Saves but why should I have to? Oh, and the escape key needed to access the menu sometimes stops working, at which point one should apparently realize that hitting shift first helps. Oh well, at least I didn't have to patch the game with specific versions of DLL files, but that reportedly happens too.Now, if you are willing to subject yourself to all of that, there's a nice, really well-voiced sci-fi story in it for you.  If not, you're probably just being sensible. Either way, I can't really recommend paying full price for the game. Sales level prices, yes, but perhaps only to fans of the genre.

												Gemini Rue is a point and click adventure game with sparse and limited fighting mechanics in various stages of the game that takes place in a dystopian sci-fi future that could be inspired easily from movies like Blade Runner. As it is expected, you explore the environment and interact with people and objects in order to solve puzzles and eventually proceed. There is also an item called the communicator which lets you communicate with various characters throughout the game but also provides you with all the necessary information and mission status.You play the role of a man named Azriel who was an ex assassin but now has left his past behind him and works as an officer against the organized crime which is run by a mafia-like group called the Boryokudan. Your formal mission is to aid a man who later helps you on your true mission which is to acquire information about your lost brother Daniel. After infiltrating the Boryokudans and reaviling that there is a secret facility where people are sent there to have their memory whipped out and re-trained to become criminals and that your brother was sent there, you gather your crew and set a new mission, rescuing your brother. The storyline despite being short is quite compelling and there are nice twists at the end as expected. The overall theme of the game is nicely expressed through the art style with retro like graphics and atmospheric music. However, I would really prefer it if instead the 16 bit overlay the visuals were a little more detailed. In comparison, the audio quality is really impressive for being an indie game. The audio logs are rich and clearly there was put a lot of effort into it. So, the audio and visuals are not side by side in my opinion. All in all, Gemini Rue is a solid adventure game following the steps of the classic ones, yet it feels fresh and modernized. All friends of the adventure genre should definitely try out this game.

In this mode, there are the following controls:A, S, D -  move left out of cover, return to cover, move right out of coverW - switch which enemy you're targetingR - reload (only works while in cover)Spacebar - shootCtrl - hold breath (only while out of cover). This causes a bar to slide up into a green zone. It takes about 3 seconds. If you shoot an enemy while it's in this zone, it will instantly kill them.The battles just devolve into the following:1. Enemy cycles between shooting at you and taking cover. A given enemy will always take cover for the same amount of time.2. Count how long they take cover for. 3. Time holding your breath with how long the enemy takes cover to get an instant kill.A few times, I found myself doing the following:  I'd press A to move out of cover to the left. Then I'd press D to try to move back into cover. But that doesn't work. You have to hit S. I think this is unintuitive. If you've associated A/D with left/right then A/D should always move you one notch to the left/right. 												Gemini Rue is a retro-style point and click adventure set on an incredibly atmospheric and stylish backdrop with an engrossing story and deeply challenging puzzles. It has all the hallmarks of classic games within the genre and is of a quality that puts some big-budget modern games to shame today. You assume the role of two characters in this intertwining story;- Azriel Odin; a former assassin who is searching for his brother whilst looking for personal redemption for his past; and a mysterious hospital patient named 'Delta Six' who's memory has been wiped for reasons unknown. Your job is to collectively discover the secrets that exist in this bleak, corrupt and crime-riddled world and provide a resolution to your characters's plight. As the narrative develops and the story unfolds; you will be hooked. For such a simple 2D game; the story is truly absorbing along with the fully-voiced characters each with an intriguing personality.The user interface is also extremely well implemented which is pivotal as this game demands complete precision in the execution of tasks and puzzles. It is incredibly complex at times and you will be forgiven for having to look up the occasional solution but it is a testament to the developers on how to create a challenging, thought-provoking and engrossing game. If you're a veteran of the genre, a fan of adventure games or just looking for a story-driven title that offers a rewarding challenge; Gemini Rue is absolutely unmissable. It captures the essence of classic games perfectly and delivers a powerful and intriguing experience throughout. One of the best titles on Steam

												I appreciate this game, but some troubles with the puzzles and the UI leave more to be desired.The adventure game this one reminds me of is Beneath a Steel Sky.  The graphics are horribly pixilated, just as games from that era were with audio and voice acting to make up for the lack of graphical attractiveness.  And it does make up for it in those areas, the characters have parts that are well written and well performed with a very human story to go alongside it.The story is one I can appreciate.  The story follows two brothers, one trying to escape a station after having his memory wiped several times and the other trying to find the station and rescue his brother.  I liked it, the reveal happened a lot earlier than the real reveal and the major reveal becomes a lot more predictable the longer you go on through the game.  However, the writing is self-aware of its own predictability and manages use it as part of the build up -to the expected result- without insulting your intellect.  Instead of happening with an unexpected bang, it happens with a silent drone of acceptance, which I thought was what the author was trying to get and fits in with the environment they were building.Most adventure games tell stories of odd worlds and go out of the way to say how different this world is from the one we live in.  This game tries hard to explain the world with experience and view we can relate to, emphasizing the people without dwelling on the sci fi, dystopia, or technology.  From that standpoint, the game is a lot more serious than most of the games filling the adventure genre.The UI and puzzles hold the experience back somewhat.  The puzzles follow the standard point and click or dialogue variety with some machine operation and event type obstacles alongside it.  The gunplay they added to the game was clunky and annoying to do.  It's easy once you manage to figure it out but it feels like something to pad the length of the game.  Some of the puzzles also have this feel, as if they were made just to lengthen the game by making you repeat content and without adding to immersion.  The UI also soured me.  It is not terrible, but some of the user unfriendly conventions of early adventure games were adopted alongside the art style.  I did have some problems trying to figure out how to use items in my inventory together, something infrequent in this game and I wish I gave more thought to the tooltip telling me how to do it the one time I had to during the game.In all, I'd say it has the bones of a good adventure game and is at least as good as the games it emulates.  Unfortunately, the UI, gunplay, and some of the puzzles leave the experience feeling clunky.  A good find for adventure game fans, less so for everyone else.

												I’m a bit biased since I don’t like adventure games. The stories are often juvenile, puzzle solutions defy logic and the games themselves don’t have much adventure. The best I can do is say that Gemini Rue isn’t terrible but too many people here are going way overboard on their praise of this game.The main reason to play adventure games (I think) is for the story. GR’s is a cut above most of what you’ll find in the adventure genre but it’s still not what I’d call “good”. It’s simply okay. Nothing particularly memorable, though there are at least a few twists thrown in.Likewise, I loathe navigating through the UIs in these games because they often turn simple tasks into complex ones because of poor design. GR has several moments like this, too, where you’ll know what has to be done but have to figure out the exact way the game prefers you do it.I will give it some points for puzzles at least having rational solutions instead of falling into the trap of “adventure game logic”. When you have to reach a ledge, for example, you’ll pull over a crate to stand on instead of throwing a rubber chicken at a cat who will get a dog to chase it who will knock over a vase which will startle a mule into kicking you up to the ledge. Again, though, it’s so annoying to have to point and click around to figure out the exact right combination of menu instructions to get up on the crate & climb up to the ledge. I’d much rather have a jump or climb button and be playing a different game.The gunfight minigame is a nice diversion from all the pointing and clicking but is inferior to any action game. It was a fun challenge, at least, to get the Steam achievement for not getting hit once during them.The graphics are retro, which means they are not so great and are around mid-1990s standards. Considering this, they at least do a good job of conveying the “dirty future” atmosphere the game is going for and set an appropriate mood.So if you like adventure games, I’d say you will enjoy GR. If you aren’t crazy about the genre, though, you won’t find anything here to change your mind.

												Gemini Rue is a point-and-click adventure game with a noire-ish science fiction theme (kind of like Blade Runner). This game was developed with Adventure Game Studio, so the graphics are extremely low resolution by any standard (320 x 200). In spite of this very low standard of graphics, the game plays very well. The point-and-click mechanics all work very well, you can interact with the environment, use inventory items, climb boxes and ladders, and engage in dialogs with characters. The main appeal of Gemini Rue is the sci-fi story. It is a very ambitious and dramatic story told without a hint of sarcasm. There are times when the story really pulls you in, which is the sign of a good story.There are also times were the story falls flat, where you can tell that the writer is a very ambitious college student (Josh Nuernburger). For instance, Boryokudan means "violent gang" in Japanese, and is the official, boring name that Japanese police have given the Yakuza so they sound less romantic. It seems Mr. Nuernberger decided Japanese was cool and typed "mafia" into an online translator. The way this word is pronounced by the voice actors is also bad. "Boryokudan" is very difficult for an English speaker to say correctly, and the voice actors have merely pronounced the word as it is spelled, with no attempt at approximating the Japanese pronunciation.The voice acting for the main characters is very good. Azriel (the main character) and the Director are excellent. For some of the lesser characters (the street vendor in particular) it seems that they just grabbed somebody off the street to read the lines.There is some challenge to this game in terms of figuring out what is going on and what is the logical next action to take, so it is engaging without being too difficult. There are a few puzzles in the game but none that I got stuck on. There were two instances where I got stuck and consulted a walkthrough, but this won't be necessary for most people (I tend to get impatient). There are a few action sequences involving shooting which are very easy.Overall I would say this is an excellent game for people who like point-and-click adventures and sci-fi stories. While very enjoyable, tt is not a perfect game and the graphics and production can seem a little amateurish at times.

												If you like point-and-click investigations, this game *may* be up your alley, and I add that caveat for one reason. I absolutely loved this game. Not only do you get to take on the (primary) role of a cop named Azriel Odin but you also get the opportunity to play as many other characters in a story that finds its way together from many seemingly unconnected strands. The only reason I warn you about playing this is because it's not a simple puzzle-solving investigatory game; it requires--it some cases--a LOT of thought, if you aren't following a guide that spells it all out for you. Not all of the puzzles are obvious, and most of them are much more difficult than you'd expect, ranging in difficulty from "no-brainer" to "it's been thirty-five minutes, what am I supposed to do with this thing?" Aside from one instance of faulty direction (you'll know what I mean when you get stuck on the lock-pick puzzle), the game is not to blame for your inability to solve the puzzle. It's to blame for forcing you to think outside the box, to examine every possible option, to go over all the things you might normally take for granted in the gaming world: in this instance, it requires you to pay close attention to details you've gained along the way. Everything is important to one degree or another and it bears mulling these details over time and again. Second, in the same vein as the aforementioned difficulty, this game makes you think--not just about puzzles but about the story, as well. I absolutely do not want to spoil this game for anyone who has an interest in playing it, so I'll refrain from citing any specifics. I think it is a very well-made game; I think it is a very important game for people to play, if they are willing to pay attention, think, and take something away from it, that is; and I think it's the kind of game that will make you almost forget you're playing it--it sort of sucks you in like a sci-fi space drama, but without all the added bull involving large scale galactic battles and strange species invading this planet or taking over that mining ship, etc. It focuses on the people and their stories, but above all, it speaks to the human condition in a profound way I've rarely seen in video games. I would whole-heartedly recommend this game to anyone who is willing to take the time to listen to what it has to say.

												Gemini Rue is an excellent Point and Click adventure with a low res, grimy, cyber-punk aesthetic.  The look and animation of the game remind me of old games I used to play on the Amiga, in a good way.  The sound design is well done as is the voice acting, though it would have been nice to have some variety in the lines that get repeated often.  The puzzles in the game are generally relatively simple, but this is for the best as it keeps them from causing too much interruption in the story which is the highlight of the game.  In the game you play the part of several characters, and at one point can even change between them to complete portions of their story in whatever order you choose.  That is one of design strengths of the game, like pretty much any game in the genre, the progression is basically linear, however there are different paths which must be explored completely to allow you ultimately progress through the story, but you can complete these paths separately or work on one them move back to another then come back to complete the first.  This both allows the game to move more naturally as you don't feel like you are on rails most of the time; and allows you to do something else and come back to it if you get stumped in your progression.  I'm not the best point and click player and often have to refer to walkthroughs to complete them.  I did have to do this two times, and in both cases it was very small objects in the environment which I didn't realize were interactive that stumped me. I liked the low res look of the game, but the pixilation probably aggravated these objects not standing out.  If there were a system to highlight the objects that were interactive, that would help to eliminate that issue.  Yes, that would be easy mode, but if I could only turn easy mode on when I really needed, it would interrupt much less than having to leave and do a Google search.  The only other minor gripe I have is that you cannot view your item inventory without first finding an interactive object.  If you like point and clicks it's a must play, if you don't then you'll find it less aggravating than most.

Gemini Rue is an old-school point and click adventure game with some action elements. The game has an involving story and unusually good use of pixelated retro graphics but is somewhat on the easy side.The game is set in a dystopian future and features a story that starts our mysterious and gradually reveals more about what is going on. The story has philosophical aspects touching on the relationship between memories and personal identity although it doesn't really explore the subjects in any great detail. The story is the best aspect of the game and is helped by the fact that there are two branches of the story unravelling at the same, the two of which later converge. I found the story very appealing and it kept me wanting to keep playing to find out what would happen.The pixelated graphics suit the atmosphere of the game very well and the visuals are nicely done. I think pixelated graphics have been overused in recent times, but here they are used to good effect.Sound effects are adequate but nothing special, voice acting on the other hand is considerably above average and matches the personalities of the characters well.The actual gameplay is the weakest aspect of the game. Puzzles are somewhat bland, not all that creative and mostly a bit too easy. The action sequences are nothing special and don't add much to the game. You could perhaps argue that in a strongly story driven game like this, having easy puzzles may be a good thing, as harder puzzles would only be frustrating when you want to make progress to find out how the story continues. Whether or not you accept that arugment I think that the somewhat lackluster gameplay pulls the game down a bit and keeps it from being the really great game that it could have been.All in all this is a highly recommended game for all point and click adventure enthusiasts, ar least if you think a good well-told story is at least as important as good gameplay.

												Gemini Rue is an excellent Point and Click adventure with a low res, grimy, cyber-punk aesthetic.  The look and animation of the game remind me of old games I used to play on the Amiga, in a good way.  The sound design is well done as is the voice acting, though it would have been nice to have some variety in the lines that get repeated often.  The puzzles in the game are generally relatively simple, but this is for the best as it keeps them from causing too much interruption in the story which is the highlight of the game.  In the game you play the part of several characters, and at one point can even change between them to complete portions of their story in whatever order you choose.  That is one of design strengths of the game, like pretty much any game in the genre, the progression is basically linear, however there are different paths which must be explored completely to allow you ultimately progress through the story, but you can complete these paths separately or work on one them move back to another then come back to complete the first.  This both allows the game to move more naturally as you don't feel like you are on rails most of the time; and allows you to do something else and come back to it if you get stumped in your progression.  I'm not the best point and click player and often have to refer to walkthroughs to complete them.  I did have to do this two times, and in both cases it was very small objects in the environment which I didn't realize were interactive that stumped me. I liked the low res look of the game, but the pixilation probably aggravated these objects not standing out.  If there were a system to highlight the objects that were interactive, that would help to eliminate that issue.  Yes, that would be easy mode, but if I could only turn easy mode on when I really needed, it would interrupt much less than having to leave and do a Google search.  The only other minor gripe I have is that you cannot view your item inventory without first finding an interactive object.  If you like point and clicks it's a must play, if you don't then you'll find it less aggravating than most.

												This game is about as old school as you can get barring text-only, though it proves that there is no such thing as going out of style when it comes to fun.Story-wise Gemini Rue is a sci-fi noir tale - in the vein of Blade Runner - about a cop searching for his missing brother in a post-war, gangster run corner of the galaxy. It is also the story of a nameless detainee in a mysterious facility where mind erasure and “re-education” are the rule. These two stories run side by side with players alternating between roles, filling in the narrative blanks until they finally come head to head during the game’s climax.As for the writing, while some of Gemini Rue’s twists, motivations, and dialogue seem hackneyed at times, they can easily be written off as contribution to the game’s pulp roots. The gameplay is mostly solid, with a decent shooting mechanic for the “action” sequences and plenty of point-and-click puzzles to solve. My only gripe is that some clickable objects are very small, requiring one to play “hunt the pixel” in order to interact. More than once this caused me to overlook an otherwise obvious solution.In the end, Gemini Rue turned out to be a pleasant experience and worth the investment. If you’re a fan of sci-fi noir, classic point-and-click adventure games, or both, you should consider checking it out.

Is a person simply the sum of all experiences and outside input or is there more to a person? Gemini Rue explores identity, ethics, and even free will. Like all great pieces of fiction, which Gemini Rue definitely is, it'll leave you contemplating the questions it poses even if it doesn't offer a concrete answer. If you're an adventure game fan or simply like the themes, setting, and story presented, you owe it to yourself to look into Gemini Rue!
